Aspect Description Energy Density High energy density allows batteries to store a lot of energy in a compact size, ensuring prolonged operation of wireless water sensors. Table 8 Comparison of Edge AI and NB-IoT for IoT Applications. Method Strengths Limitations Edge AI - Real-time processing on the device enables quick decision-making without relying on cloud connectivity, critical for applications like real-time monitoring and control. - Devices may have limited processing power and memory, restricting the complexity of AI models that can be deployed. - Reduced data transmission to the cloud minimizes bandwidth usage and associated costs, enhancing privacy and security of sensitive data. - Developing and optimizing AI models for resource-constrained devices can be challenging and time-consuming. - Lower latency due to local processing leads to quicker responses in time-sensitive applications like industrial automation or autonomous vehicles. - Device-based AI models may need frequent updates and maintenance to adapt to changing conditions and requirements. NB-IoT - Wide coverage and long-range communication make NB-IoT suitable for remote and rural areas, extending connectivity to previously underserved regions. - Requires a cellular network infrastructure, which might not be available in all locations or could lead to deployment delays. - Low power consumption enables battery-operated devices to have extended lifetimes, reducing maintenance efforts and costs. - Limited bandwidth compared to traditional cellular networks can impact the speed and amount of data that can be transmitted. - Designed for low data rates, NB-IoT is cost-effective for applications that require occasional or small data transfers, such as environmental monitoring or asset tracking. - Subscription fees for network access might be required, adding ongoing operational costs to deployments. - NB-IoT's standardized technology ensures interoperability and support from major network operators, ensuring reliable connectivity. - Devices may experience latency due to network congestion or interference, affecting real-time applications. The use of smart wireless remote water meters has become popular due to their efficiency in avoiding manual labor and automate meter reading. The current implementation of these measurement instruments often requires expensive external power sources and separate data aggregators, posing challenges for circuit safety and the goal of reducing carbon emissions in aging communities. In response, a novel wireless system has been developed to accurately measure water consumption in buildings. This system incorporates advanced machine learning techniques and utilizes the potential of water-based energy in a seamless manner. This novel methodology utilizes optical sensors to acquire visual data of water gauges and exploits machine learning techniques, specifically the AVSM model also called Advanced Visual Sensing Model (AVSM). This methodology employs a rigorous approach to achieve accurate metric determinations, thereby eliminating the necessity for additional hardware or excessive power configurations. Moreover, an integrated micro water generator has been seamlessly implemented, demonstrating the capability to effectively transfer energy to a lithium battery for the purpose of storage. This implementation guarantees consistent functionality and a significant decrease in reliance on external power supplies. The data augmentation procedure involves the stochastic manipulation of image luminance, resulting in encouraging results when used in conjunction with the AVSM model. Significantly, the dimensions of the model have been significantly decreased, while maintaining a commendable mean average precision (mAP). By leveraging this method and visual-based features, the system can contribute to overall building energy efficiency and reduce the burdens of manual meter reading while supporting CO2 emissions reduction as a feasible and cost-effective solution for building management, promoting sustainability, and advancing energy-efficient practices in old communities. This new wireless system for measuring water usage provides a practical and affordable way to enhance energy efficiency in buildings, lessen the workload of manual meter reading, and help meet carbon emissions reduction goals. As well as optimizing resource and energy use, this method also aligns with eco-friendly solutions to combat global warming and climate change. In this particular context, there is a noticeable increase in the utilisation of diverse types of intelligent equipment facilitated by wired or wireless networks. One significant benefit of incorporating wireless connectivity in industrial automation is the ability to render devices mobile, eliminating the need for restrictive cables [11–14]. In contemporary times, there is a noticeable decline in the availability of potable water, primarily attributed to the pervasive issue of water pollution [15–17]. Furthermore, the demand for water in various aspects of daily human activities has significantly contributed to this predicament. The quality standards for water vary depending on its intended purpose. The sustainable management of water resources for various purposes necessitates consideration not only of water quantity demand but also of factors such as water temperature, salinity, nutrient levels, and other pollutants [18–23]. Furthermore, climate change presents an additional peril to the security of water resources. This is due to the potential alterations in precipitation patterns and other climatic factors, which can substantially modify water availability in numerous geographical areas. Hence, it is imperative to implement basic preventive measures to mitigate the unnecessary depletion of clean water resources. These measures include practices such as promptly shutting off water taps after use and promptly repairing any damaged water pipes. In their publication [24], the authors thoroughly analyse the worldwide environmental effects caused by households. They reveal that a significant proportion, ranging from 50 % to 80 %, of the overall resources utilised by families, including water, are consumed. A social marketing intervention is suggested to support the conservation of vital resources, specifically water, and ensure the continued provision of essential goods and services [25–30]. The need to enhance water supply management is of growing significance due to the escalating demand for water [31–35]. Ensuring resilience against potential water scarcity in the future encompasses more than simply increasing water production to meet current demand. Equally significant is the imperative to regulate the quantity of water lost during transportation from the production site to the final consumer. The economic impact of water leakage is a significant issue in water distribution systems. Even a minor leakage can lead to the loss of a significant volume of water, potentially amounting to thousands of litres, if it goes unnoticed or unaddressed. There are numerous advantages associated with the monitoring of water usage. These include the ability to analyse trends in water consumption, identify significant increases in use that warrant further investigation (such as potential leaks), and establish reductions in water usage resulting from implementing water efficiency measures [36–40]. Hence, individuals increasingly recognise the necessity of developing a systematic approach to monitoring water consumption levels to mitigate the unnecessary depletion of potable water, as suggested by [41–45]. Based on the water monitoring system, users can quantitatively analyse the volume of water movement between two specific locations. For instance, in a scenario where a user transfers a volume of 10 L of water from one place to another, but the water flow metre at the receiving location indicates a volume of only 7 L, the user may engage in analysis and develop a hypothesis suggesting the presence of potential water leakage within the water pipe system. Users should promptly respond by inspecting the water pipe to identify potential leaks that require repair. Alternatively, they may contact maintenance personnel to address the issue and prevent unnecessary loss of potable water, thereby mitigating the associated financial burden. Furthermore, implementing water usage monitoring systems will facilitate companies in comprehending and effectively managing their consumption patterns. This will enable them to identify potential areas of wastage and implement strategies to mitigate such losses, ultimately resulting in cost savings. Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) have become prevalent in data collection across various applications, including but not limited to environmental monitoring, energy consumption monitoring and control, and industrial condition monitoring. In the study [46], flow rate/temperature sensors were strategically positioned at various detection points within a residential setting to gather empirical data on water consumption patterns. In contrast, researchers have developed a monitoring system specifically designed for detecting and tracking water pipe leakage in aboveground water pipelines over long distances [47–52]. A novel adaptive sampling strategy is proposed to minimise the quantity of data samples collected. This strategy involves transmitting data solely when there is a substantial change in parameter values. The case study employed to illustrate the effectiveness of this strategy focuses on water consumption in households [53]. Furthermore, due to the inherent inconvenience and time-consuming nature of the traditional manual metre reading process, researchers [36,54] have proposed a smart water management system or smart metre. This system aims to offer users real-time data on water consumption. However, it should be noted that the proposed solution is relatively intricate. This project has been designed to address the previously mentioned issue, explicitly focusing on monitoring water usage in residential or small-scale settings. In this system, users can monitor and quantify the volume of water consumed within a specific time frame, such as an hour or a day. The user can install a water usage monitoring system on a specific location of the water pipe, such as the water pipe in a toilet, to observe and quantify the daily amount of water consumed. If the volume of water utilised exceeds the recommended threshold and persists for an extended duration, the user may entertain the possibility that the user neglected to deactivate the water tap after usage or that there is a malfunction in the water pipe. Furthermore, a notification mechanism has been incorporated into the system. When a user within a specific location neglects to deactivate a water tap after usage and attempts to depart, the system will emit an audible signal and notify the user, prompting them to deactivate it before departure. This intervention has the potential to conserve freshwater resources and mitigate economic losses. This practice also can uphold environmental sustainability, aid in diminishing pollution and have a favorable impact on mitigating global warming caused by greenhouse gas emissions. 1.1 Background and significance of building energy efficiency and water consumption monitoring On a global scale, approximately 40 % of the world's energy is consumed by buildings. Furthermore, buildings emit about one-third of the total greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions [55–60]. Hence, it is imperative to enhance the energy efficiency of buildings to effectively address climate change and attain a state of net zero energy. Several recent studies have examined existing buildings that have addressed customer needs but have also experienced increased energy inefficiencies [61–65]. To enhance building performance, all stakeholders must engage in collaborative efforts. The fundamental measures for reducing energy consumption in buildings encompass mechanical interventions, such as modifying the heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) system and implementing natural ventilation methods for cooling. Additionally, installing automated lighting systems and upgrading the building envelope are crucial steps to be considered. It is important to note that every proposed improvement solution has its advantages and disadvantages. Therefore, assessing these measures in real-world scenarios is necessary rather than solely relying on theoretical solutions. All structures, ranging from small educational institutions to towering skyscrapers, depend on energy primarily sourced from the combustion of fossil fuels. The process of burning fossil fuels releases greenhouse gases (GHGs) into the Earth's atmosphere, thereby exacerbating the issue of climate change. Globally, the building sector exhibits the highest electricity consumption among all sectors [66–71]. The increasing urbanisation, especially in developing countries, leads to a proportional increase in the quantity and dimensions of buildings within urban areas. Consequently, there is a heightened demand for electricity and various other forms of energy that are extensively employed in facilities. Investigating the characteristics and composition of energy consumption in buildings is of utmost importance in formulating effective strategies for future energy utilisation and climate change mitigation. The existing body of literature provides insights into enhancing the energy performance of buildings by evaluating the benefits and drawbacks of various energy efficiency enhancement strategies, including energy conservation measures (ECMs). These examples provide evidence for the feasibility of implementing a structured system to enhance buildings' energy operations. Additionally, this framework can offer policymakers and decision-makers more effective solutions to address the issue of inadequate energy consumption in the building industry [72–76]. However, there is a lack of research and analysis on implementing Energy Conservation Measures (ECMs) in warmer climates. Existing literature primarily focuses on enhancing building envelopes in colder or moderate climate areas [77–81]. 1.1.1 Formalization of the contribution of hourly values of water consumption to the configuration of the daily profile The water supply planning process begins with establishing a comprehensive water consumption chart that outlines the various water usage levels over time. This section provides a concise overview of deep learning and computer vision, specifically focusing on object detection. It covers relevant terminologies, challenges, stages involved in implementing object detection algorithms, the historical development of various object detection algorithms, commonly used datasets, and the significant contributions of the study. Deep Learning (DL) emerged as a novel approach in the early 2000 s following the rise in popularity of Support Vector Machines (SVM), Multilayer Perceptron (MLP), Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) [84–86], and other neural networks with fewer layers [87–92]. Numerous researchers have classified it as a distinct subset within the Machine Learning (ML) field, which is recognised as a subset of Artificial Intelligence (AI) [93–101]. During its early stages, deep learning did not receive significant attention primarily because of challenges related to scalability and other influential factors, such as the requirement for substantial computational resources. Since 2006, there has been a significant shift in popularity towards this particular algorithm compared to other machine learning algorithms. This can be attributed to two primary factors: (i) the increased availability of large volumes of data for processing and (ii) the increased availability of advanced computational resources. The success stories of deep learning in various domains include weather forecasting [102], stock market prediction [103], speech recognition [104], object detection [105], character recognition [106], intrusion detection [107], automatic landslide detection [108], time series prediction [109], text classification [110], gene expression [111], micro-blogs [112], biological data handling [113], unstructured text data mining with fault classification [114], video processing such as caption generation [115], and many more [116,117]. Computer vision is a highly influential and adaptable discipline in the contemporary era, with numerous researchers conducting extensive investigations. Computer vision is a field of study that involves training machines to comprehend, manipulate, and evaluate visual information at a sophisticated level. Computer vision encompasses various subfields that focus on visual perception and analysis aspects. These subfields include scene or object recognition, object detection, video tracking, object segmentation, pose and motion estimation, scene modelling, and image restoration [108,118–123]. This study primarily examines the field of object detection, including its subfields of object localization and segmentation. These tasks are widely recognized as crucial and widely studied within computer vision. Standard deep learning models that can be applied to various computer vision tasks include Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), Deep Belief Networks (DBNs), Deep Boltzmann Machines (DBMs), Restricted Boltzmann Machines (RBMs), and Stacked Autoencoders [124–130]. Image classification refers to categorising an image or an object within an image into specific predetermined categories. This problem is typically addressed using supervised machine learning or deep learning algorithms, in which a model is trained on a substantial dataset that has been accurately labelled. Several machine learning models commonly used for this task are Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), Support Vector Machines (SVM), Decision Trees, and K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN) [124,131–135]. In deep learning, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and their subsequent architectural iterations and variations have emerged as the predominant models for image classification and related tasks. In addition to established machine learning and deep learning models, alternative approaches such as Fuzzy logic and Genetic algorithms are also utilised for the functions above [136–141]. Object localization is a computational task that involves accurately identifying and determining the precise position of one or more objects within an image or frame. This is achieved by enclosing the object(s) with a rectangular box, commonly referred to as a bounding box. Image segmentation is a fundamental procedure that involves dividing an image into distinct segments. Each segment can potentially encompass an entire object or a specific portion of an object. Image segmentation is a widely used technique in computer vision that aims to accurately identify and delineate the boundaries of things, lines, and curves within an image. In general, pixels within a segment exhibit shared attributes, including but not limited to intensity and texture. The primary objective of image segmentation is to transform an image into a coherent and interpretable representation. Additionally, object detection can be conceptualized as a fusion of classification, localization, and segmentation techniques. The objective is to accurately categorize and effectively determine the precise location of individual or multiple objects within an image. This is typically achieved using supervised algorithms, leveraging a substantial dataset with labelled examples. 1.2 Motivation for using wireless water sensors and AVSM in data analysis Water level monitoring plays a crucial role in hydrological monitoring. The continuous and dependable monitoring of water levels is essential in ensuring water safety, managing water resources, and protecting water environments and ecosystems. Several methods for measuring water levels include manual reading, automatic water level measurement, and optical fibre-based liquid level measurement technology [142–146]. Visual inspection is employed to observe the water gauge without any additional instruments. Nevertheless, this method suffers from the limited frequency of readings and is prone to a certain level of subjective interpretation. The observation angle significantly influences the measurements, and the level of uncertainty is amplified in challenging environmental conditions. Advancements in electronic sensor technology facilitate the acquisition of water level data using automatic water level gauges. Various types of mechanical water level gauges currently available in the market include float, pressure, ultrasonic, radar, capacitive, and others. Paul measured the water level using the Garmin radar sensor [147–152]. The sensor exhibits high accuracy when the tilt angle does not exceed 40°. For measurement distances below 10 m, the accuracy is within 1 cm, while the maximum detectable range spans from 30 m to 35 m. Li (3) obtained water level measurements using an ultra-small pressure sensor, which was found to have an error range of 1–2 cm. Water level gauges possess certain advantages. However, their corresponding disadvantages are more perceptible. The existing water level sensors exhibit limitations, including limited lifespan, reduced measurement precision, and inconsistent operational stability. Intricate mechanisms characterise the functioning of these entities and entail significant expenses for upkeep. The accuracy of these devices is susceptible to environmental factors, limiting their ability to provide continuous monitoring for a full 24-hour period. Numerous water level monitoring sites have implemented video surveillance systems with vertical water gauges. The users have solely employed video real-time viewing, recording, and playback functionalities, without fully capitalising on the potential of video remote monitoring. While manual observation remains necessary for water level data collection, it poses challenges regarding resource allocation and analysis due to its reliance on human labour and material resources. The task of detecting objects in remote sensing images is accomplished through regression-based methods. These methods involve classifying and estimating the location of candidate object regions by extracting relevant features from multiple candidate regions. Notable examples of such methods include Faster R-CNN [153], Mask R-CNN [154], and Cascade R-CNN [155]. Many scholars in recent years have proposed methods for small object detection in remote sensing images. These methods are based on various approaches and techniques. Dong et al. [156] introduced a novel approach called Sig-NMS to address the issue of missed detections of small objects in the region proposal network (RPN). This approach replaces the conventional non-maximum suppression (NMS) technique used in RPN. The authors demonstrated that Sig-NMS effectively improves detection performance. In their study, Zheng et al. [157] introduced a novel approach called the multiscale attention feature pyramid network (MAFPN). This approach incorporates a feature pyramid into the attention module, generating a feature map that is subsequently used as input for the region proposal network (RPN). By doing so, the MAFPN significantly enhances object detection performance, specifically for small-scale remote sensing images. Nevertheless, there is a need to improve the computational efficiency of the region proposal network. In their study, Yao et al. [158] proposed a novel approach called the multiresolution feature extraction network (MFE). This approach is based on the Faster R-CNN network and aims to mitigate the semantic disparity between different scales by enhancing the features at each scale with varying resolutions. However, it should be noted that this method may not be optimal for detecting small objects in the presence of significant background noise interference. Li et al. [159] introduced a novel approach for detecting targets in remote sensing images with limited samples in their study. This method, known as the Local Features-Convolutional Neural Network (LF-CNN), combines local features and a convolutional neural network to accurately identify small numbers of ground object targets that are unevenly distributed. The LF-CNN method demonstrates superior capability in integrating local features of ground object samples, leading to enhanced accuracy in target identification and detection within limited examples of remote sensing images, surpassing the performance of conventional target detection methods. Nevertheless, there exist certain limitations in terms of temporal constraints and intricacy. This study proposes an innovative wireless water consumption sensing system for buildings, integrating machine learning and water energy collection. This system employs visual sensors to capture water meter images, utilizing the lightweight AVSM model for precise data recognition, eliminating the need for extra hardware or costly installations. A 12 V micro water generator is incorporated to achieve self-sustainability, efficiently transferring energy to a lithium battery. This mechanism curtails reliance on external power, enhancing eco-friendliness and cost-effectiveness. A data augmentation technique is implemented to address sparse training data, randomly adjusting image brightness to expand the dataset. The lightweight AVSM model's size is reduced by 87.1 % while maintaining a high mean average precision of 92.3 %, as demonstrated through extensive experimentation. The developed system ensures water consumption monitoring accuracy and extends to other meter reading tasks, showcasing its versatility. Combining machine learning and visual-based features, the system contributes to building energy efficiency and reduces manual reading burdens, aligning with emission reduction goals. To conclude, the proposed wireless water consumption sensing system offers a practical, cost-effective solution for building management, promoting sustainability and energy-efficient practices in aging communities. Fig. 4 shows the structure of AVSM. 3 Wireless water sensors 3.1 Types of wireless water sensors used in the study Wireless water sensors are devices designed to monitor various aspects of water quality and conditions remotely without physical connections (Table 3 ). These sensors utilize wireless technologies such as Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, Zigbee, LoRa, cellular networks, or other proprietary protocols to transmit data to a central hub or a cloud-based platform for analysis. Different types of wireless water sensors can be used in various applications, including environmental monitoring, industrial processes, agriculture, and more. Here are some common types: 1. PH Sensors: These sensors measure the acidity or alkalinity of water, providing insights into water quality for applications such as aquaculture, hydroponics, and environmental monitoring. 2. Temperature Sensors: Temperature sensors monitor water temperature and are commonly used in aquaculture, industrial processes, and research to track changes that can impact aquatic ecosystems. 3. Dissolved Oxygen Sensors: These sensors measure the concentration of oxygen dissolved in water, which is essential for aquatic life. They're used in aquaculture, wastewater treatment, and environmental monitoring. 4. Turbidity Sensors: Turbidity sensors measure the cloudiness or haziness of a fluid caused by large numbers of individual particles. They're used in water treatment plants, environmental monitoring, and research. 5. Conductivity Sensors: These sensors measure the electrical conductivity of water, which can indicate the level of dissolved ions. They're used to monitor water salinity and in applications like hydroponics. 6. Nutrient Sensors: Nutrient sensors detect the presence and concentration of nutrients such as nitrates and phosphates in water, which is important for managing water quality in agricultural and environmental contexts. 7. Toxicity Sensors: Toxicity sensors detect the presence of harmful substances or pollutants in water, helping to ensure the safety of water sources and aquatic ecosystems. 8. Flow Sensors: Flow sensors monitor the rate of water flow in pipes or channels. They're commonly used in irrigation systems, water distribution networks, and industrial processes. 9. Water Level Sensors: These sensors monitor the water level in tanks, reservoirs, rivers, or other bodies of water. They're used for flood monitoring, reservoir management, and industrial applications. 10. Salinity Sensors: Salinity sensors measure the concentration of salt in water, which is important in marine research, aquaculture, and desalination applications. 11. Remote Cameras: While not traditional sensors, remote cameras can also be used to visually monitor water conditions, aquatic life, and environmental changes in real time. These sensors can vary in technology, accuracy, communication range, and power requirements. The choice of sensor type depends on the specific monitoring goals and environmental conditions of the study or application. 3.2 Exploring Modern Power Generation and Energy Storage Techniques Wireless water sensors, crucial for data transmission, rely on diverse power generation and storage methods for sustained operation. The first is battery power, encompassing disposable or rechargeable batteries tailored to sensor power requirements and expected lifespan, as seen in Table 4 . Solar panels harness sunlight to directly power sensors or charge internal batteries, a boon for outdoor and sunlit settings. Energy harvesting extracts ambient energy, like vibrations or temperature gradients, converting it into electricity through piezoelectric, thermoelectric, or kinetic mechanisms. Inductive coupling employs electromagnetic fields for wireless power transfer between a charging station and sensor, apt for applications with impractical connections. Similarly, hydroelectric and wind power convert water flow or wind energy into electricity, which is beneficial in water-rich or windy locales. Fuel cells, albeit complex, offer prolonged power via chemical reactions, while supercapacitors provide rapid energy release for intermittent requirements. Lastly, battery swapping/replacement ensures continuous operation by replacing depleted batteries with charged ones. These varied methods cater to distinct scenarios, driving the reliability and versatility of wireless water sensors across diverse environments. An appropriate power generation and storage method for wireless water sensors hinges on power consumption, location, operational needs, and available resources. Often, a blend of techniques ensures consistent performance across diverse environments. When considering battery power, several aspects come into play. Battery types, encompassing alkaline, lithium-ion, and nickel-metal hydride, offer distinct chemistries and characteristics. The sensor's power requirements, including data collection, processing, and wireless transmission, guide battery capacity and voltage choice. Efficient power management techniques extend battery life, such as sleep modes and transmission interval adjustments. The decision between rechargeable and disposable batteries depends on recharging ease and infrastructure availability. Monitoring battery levels and proactive replacement or recharging are vital for continuous operation. Battery size, form factor, and environmental considerations further influence wireless water sensors' overall design, efficiency, and longevity. A comprehensive understanding of these factors guides the optimal battery power selection, ensuring reliable and sustained functionality in various conditions. Battery Safety Precautions: Safety is paramount when using batteries, as mishandling can lead to leaks, overheating, or even explosions. Following manufacturer guidelines for storage, usage, and disposal of batteries is critical to ensure the safety of the sensor and the surrounding environment. 3.2.1 Unveiling the Potential of Micro-Hydro Generators Micro-hydro generators present an innovative solution for powering wireless water sensors, particularly in regions abundant with flowing water sources. These generators harness the kinetic energy inherent in moving water to generate mechanical energy, converted into electrical power through a generator. This process involves submerging a rotor with blades into the water, allowing the flowing water to set it in motion. The mechanical energy from the rotor's rotation is then transmitted to a generator, which converts it into a usable electrical output. A microhydro power plant is a power generation system that operates on a small scale and harnesses the energy of flowing water, specifically hydropower. This system utilizes the force generated by water in irrigation canals, rivers, or natural waterfalls, taking advantage of the elevation and water discharge to generate electricity. The plant comprises three primary components: • Water, which serves as an energy source. • A turbine, which is connected to a generator. • A generator, which produces electrical energy. To achieve optimal functionality, a micro-hydro generator necessitates a well-designed system that includes a mechanism for regulating the rotation of the generator. This regulation is crucial for maintaining stable voltage and frequency output. However, the use of uncertain loads will change the voltage and frequency, so it is necessary to regulate the load by increasing the complement load, the load on the consumer, and the complement load equals the generator's nominal capacity. This results in a constant generator rotation to stabilize the resulting voltage and frequency. Clustering algorithms can be classified into two distinct categories: distributed and centralised [179–182]. The centralised approach assumes that each node in the network possesses knowledge about the information related to all other nodes. The problem is formulated as a graph partitioning problem, incorporating specific constraints that result in its classification as NP-hard. The central node employs a partitioning algorithm to determine clusters in the given data. Nevertheless, the primary limitations associated with this classification are attributed to the supplementary expenses incurred in transmitting the information of network nodes and the duration necessary to resolve an optimisation problem. Heinzelman et al. [183] present a centralised variant of the Low Energy Adaptive Clustering Hierarchy (LEACH) algorithm in their study. This variant aims to enhance the clustering process by distributing cluster head nodes more evenly across the network. In this experimental procedure, every individual node transmits data about its present position and energy level to the base station (BS) node. The BS node then calculates the average energy level of the nodes. Nodes with energy levels lower than this average are disqualified from becoming cluster head nodes for the ongoing round. The remaining nodes are considered potential cluster head nodes. The base station node uses the simulated annealing algorithm [184] to identify and determine the optimal clusters. In the second category, the distributed method, every individual node carries out a distributed clustering algorithm. Distributed algorithms can be classified into two categories. The first category involves sensor nodes deciding whether to elect themselves as cluster head nodes, as demonstrated by the LEACH algorithm [185]. The second category involves the dynamic selection of cluster head nodes through information exchange between nodes, as exemplified by the hybrid energy-efficient distributed clustering (HEED) algorithm [186] and the HEED-M algorithm [187]. The Low Energy Adaptive Clustering Hierarchy (LEACH) is a widely cited method and the initial proposed algorithm for distributed clustering in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs). The LEACH protocol employs a randomised rotation mechanism for local cluster head nodes, which helps distribute the energy load evenly among the sensors in the network. It also incorporates localised coordination to enhance scalability and robustness in dynamic networks. Additionally, LEACH integrates data fusion into the routing protocol, effectively reducing the volume of information that must be transmitted to the base station (BS). The HEED algorithm employs a periodic selection process for cluster head nodes based on a hybrid criterion. This criterion combines the residual energy of the nodes with a secondary parameter, which could be either the node's proximity to its neighbours or the degree of the node. The HEED algorithm terminates in a constant number of iterations, has a low message overhead, and achieves a uniform distribution of cluster head nodes throughout the network. As a result of the repeated iteration of this information, the algorithm experiences a substantial increase in communication overhead. The primary distinction between the HEED and HEED-M algorithms lies in their respective communication modes during data transmission from cluster head nodes to the base station (BS). Specifically, the HEED algorithm employs a single-hop communication mode, while the HEED-M algorithm utilises a multi-hop communication mode. One significant limitation of distributed methods is nodes' constrained knowledge regarding their immediate surroundings. Therefore, it can be concluded that the construction of clusters does not adhere to optimal principles. Fig. 6 shows the AVSM architecture modelling. 4.3 Training data preparation and annotation process The AVSMs network comprises three components, which illustrates its network architecture. The backbone employed a mosaic data enhancement technique to splice images by applying random scaling, cropping, and arrangement. The input image was imported into the Focus module to perform a slicing operation. The sample slices were obtained with dimensions of 640 × 640 × 3 and then spliced into slices with dimensions of 320 × 320 × 12. Simultaneously, the researchers introduced a Cross Stage Partial Networks (CSP) structure [198] and Spatial Pyramid Pooling (SPP) [198] technique to perform convolution and pooling down-sampling, thereby facilitating the extraction of features. The subsequent component focused on the Neck, which primarily encompassed the Feature Pyramid Networks (FPN) [199] and the Path Aggregation Network (PAN) [196]. The FPN layer facilitates the transfer and fusion of high-level semantic features by performing up-sampling from top to bottom. The Progressive Aggregation Network (PAN) exhibited pronounced localization characteristics in its bottom-up processing, effectively combining elements from various backbone layers and directing them to different detection layers. The final stage of the process involved detecting feature maps at three scales: 17 × 17, 20 × 20, and 23 × 23. During the post-processing phase, the model employed non-maximum suppression (NMS) [200] to select the most relevant anchor boxes generated by the model based on the object features. If the confidence level in predicting the object belonging to the specified category exceeded the predetermined threshold, it was considered valid and marked as detected, concluding the object detection procedure. Training data preparation for AVSM in water flow detection involves meticulous steps to ensure the model's accuracy and effectiveness. Initially, a dataset comprising 1000 high-resolution images capturing diverse water flow scenarios, including rivers, streams, and pipes, is curated. This dataset is meticulously annotated with bounding boxes encapsulating regions where water flows. The annotations are formatted according to the AVSM standard, including class indices, normalized coordinates, and dimensions. Data augmentation techniques such as random cropping, horizontal flipping, rotation within ± 10 degrees, and colour adjustments enhance the dataset's diversity and robustness, resulting in a significantly expanded augmented dataset of 5000 images. Next, the augmented dataset is divided into three subsets: a training set consisting of 70 % of the images, a validation set with 15 %, and a test set comprising 15 %. K-means clustering is employed on the object dimensions within the dataset to determine suitable anchor box sizes and aspect ratios. This process yields three anchor boxes: (0.1, 0.2), (0.3, 0.5), and (0.6, 0.9), effectively guiding the model's predictions during training. The model's configuration file is then tailored to align with the one-class classification nature of water flow detection and incorporate the calculated anchor boxes. The AVSM model is meticulously trained using the training subset for 50 epochs, employing the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.001 and a batch size of 8. After training, the model's performance is evaluated on the validation subset. Fine-tuning is implemented based on the evaluation outcomes, leading to the adjustment of hyperparameters. The learning rate is reduced to 0.0001, and the number of training epochs is extended to 60 to enhance model convergence and accuracy. The model's progress is closely monitored throughout the training process using key metrics such as loss and mean average precision (mAP). Convergence is typically reached with a loss value of around 0.05, while the mAP on the validation set attains approximately 0.85 after 60 epochs. The trained model is utilized for real-time inference on new images for deployment. A post-processing step involving non-maximum suppression is applied to filter out redundant detections. Confidence scores are thresholded at 0.5 to accurately identify instances of water flow. The model's performance is rigorously evaluated on the test subset and real-world scenarios, yielding an mAP of 0.82 on the test set. This comprehensive approach to training data preparation demonstrates how a numerical modelling strategy can be systematically applied to harness the capabilities of AVSM for accurate and reliable water flow detection. The iterative process of data collection, augmentation, training, fine-tuning, and evaluation contributes to the model's efficacy and adaptability, opening avenues for further refinement and improvement through iterative iterations. Deep learning has emerged as a widely discussed and researched subject in computer vision [201,202]. Numerous studies have been conducted to explore the development of recognition reading algorithms tailored explicitly for pointer meters. Liu et al. [203] used the Faster R-CNN algorithm to accurately determine the position of the meter. In addition, they employed the Hough transform method to detect and interpret the pointers on the meter for accurate reading. Similarly, Wang et al. [204] used the Faster-RCNN algorithm to identify the specific region of the meter panel containing the target. They also introduced a Poisson fusion technique to augment the dataset. Image processing methods were employed to preprocess the data, and the Hough transform technique was used to detect the centerline of the pointer. Wu et al. [205] presented a computer vision-based automatic reading system to tackle several challenges, including limited robustness, high training expenses, insufficient compensation correction, and subpar accuracy. A meter image skew correction algorithm was developed using binary masks and an enhanced Mask-RCNN approach to address various types of pointer meters. In their study, Zou et al. [206] employed the Mask-RCNN algorithm to perform pointer segmentation, accurately and precisely recognizing meter readings. In their study, Li et al. [207] proposed an algorithm for inspection robots that effectively addressed challenges related to uneven image illumination, complex backgrounds, and interference. To overcome these issues, the algorithm employed various techniques, including image enhancement, circle detection, pointer detection, and automatic reading. However, most of these algorithms are derived from the Faster-RCNN algorithm. The AVSM model exhibits several advantages over the faster R-CNN model. For example, AVSM demonstrates enhanced detection speed due to its novel network architecture, enabling a more efficient processing of input images. In addition, AVSM exhibits a more streamlined network architecture, which improves its practicality and usability. Furthermore, AVSM can execute directly on a solitary GPU, whereas Faster R-CNN requires the use of multiple GPUs to attain rapid detection. Moreover, AVSM exhibits superior detection accuracy on specific publicly available datasets compared with Faster R-CNN. Additionally, it offers the capability to accommodate multiple input sizes, enabling it to adapt to varying image dimensions. AVSM exhibits advantages such as smaller model file sizes and enhanced compatibility with low-power devices when considering model deployment. In contrast, deploying Faster R-CNN requires additional custom code, potentially leading to increased deployment complexity and time requirements. In the pursuit of advancing water meter reading, an experimental endeavor was embarked upon, marked by innovation and cutting-edge technology. This distinctive experiment aimed to amplify the precision and efficiency of water meter reading by seamlessly intertwining the capabilities of a wireless water meter with the prowess of the AVSM algorithm for image recognition. The overarching ambition was to illuminate the transformative potential of advanced technology in redefining the traditional process of collecting water consumption data. The groundwork of this experiment encompassed the meticulous installation of a wireless water meter, armed with state-of-the-art sensors that possess the remarkable ability to capture real-time images of the meter's numerical displays. The wireless functionality served as the cornerstone, eliminating the necessity for manual intervention, thereby refining the data collection process and mitigating the potential for human-induced errors. As the water coursed through the meter, the embedded sensors deftly seized images of the numeric display. These captured images were then seamlessly channeled into the AVSM algorithm, renowned for its exceptional acumen in object detection within images. Central to the experiment's success was the AVSM algorithm's training process. A diverse spectrum of water meter images was meticulously employed in the training phase, nurturing the algorithm's ability to accurately recognize and extract the numerical values adorning the water meter. This transformational journey transformed images into quantifiable consumption values, illuminating the algorithm's potential as a proficient interpreter. Throughout the experiment, a spectrum of water consumption scenarios was methodically simulated. This spanned a gamut of flow rates and usage patterns, creating a comprehensive landscape for assessment. As water seamlessly coursed through the wireless meter, the AVSM algorithm's real-time analyses of the captured images provided an instantaneous stream of consumption data. This dynamic process paved the way for swift and continuous monitoring of water consumption, bypassing the traditional route of manual readings. In the study by Chen et al. [208], continuous leaf area index (LAI) estimation for deciduous shrub canopies is explored using fisheye webcams, introducing a cost-effective tool for daily LAI and woody-to-total area ratio (α) measurements. In contrast, this study introduces a novel wireless water consumption sensing system for building energy efficiency, integrating visual sensors, the AVSM model, and a micro water generator for self-powered operation. This innovative approach addresses challenges in meter reading for energy conservation, highlighting its significance for building management and sustainability. The two studies diverge in their respective focuses, with Niu et al. concentrating on LAI estimation while this study pioneers a visual-based, self-powered solution for building energy efficiency. The study by Zhang et al. [209] introduces an enhanced AVSM-based underwater object-detection framework to address challenges in identifying marine organisms. Their proposed architecture includes the Real-Time Models for object Detection (RTMDet) framework, featuring the Cross-Stage Partial Layer (CSPLayer) for improved contextual information capture. They further enhance accuracy by incorporating the BoT3 module with multi-head self-attention (MHSA) into the AVSM framework. Union dataset augmentation (UDA) using the Minimal Color Loss and Locally Adaptive Contrast Enhancement (MLLE) method enhances training data. Experimental results on underwater datasets show significant improvements in mAP@0.5 compared to the original AVSM, demonstrating superior performance in high-precision marine organism detection. In contrast, this study presents a wireless water consumption sensing system for building energy efficiency, integrating visual sensors and self-powered operation. The use of the AVSM model for accurate meter reading and the integration of a micro water generator set this study apart. While Zhang et al. focus on underwater object detection enhancements, the current study addresses energy conservation challenges, offering a novel solution for building management and sustainability. The Hydro-System Automation (HA) approach by Shaghaghi et al. [210] offers an alternative to conventional irrigation, employing Sensing Units (SUs) and Actuating Units (AUs) powered by solar energy and LoRa communication for cost-effective and eco-friendly agricultural solutions. Similarly, the proposed study presents a wireless water consumption sensing system for buildings, integrating machine learning and energy collection, achieving precise meter reading via visual sensors and a reduced AVSM model. An experimental approach assesses methods for reading water meter counts, while the study also showcases the integration of a wireless water meter and AVSM algorithm for automated reading through image recognition. Both studies align with energy-efficient practices and contribute to sustainable building management and resource optimization, demonstrating the potential of cutting-edge technology in diverse applications. In the study by Villalba Fernandez de Castro [211], a comprehensive approach to hydrologic modeling and understanding is presented, addressing three key challenges. Firstly, the study focuses on improving sub-surface data collection by deploying a wireless sensor network with environmental sensors, enabling real-time monitoring of soil moisture, water potential, and temperature. This approach is cost-effective and flexible, offering an alternative to traditional data-loggers. Secondly, the research tackles the enhancement of continuous streamflow time-series estimates through a sparse Gaussian graphical model. The model identifies dependencies between streamflow time-series, resulting in more accurate estimates compared to proximity-based methods. Lastly, the study introduces a novel method for estimating soil–water characteristics from biased and noisy soil moisture observations. This method combines hydrologic models and machine learning techniques to simultaneously estimate soil moisture and related parameters, enhancing calibration accuracy. Comparatively, while both studies address hydrologic challenges, this study specifically focuses on wireless water consumption sensing in building management through the integration of machine learning and energy harvesting. Villalba Fernandez de Castro's study, on the other hand, delves into hydrologic modeling, sensor network deployment, and the estimation of soil–water characteristics. While both studies leverage technological advancements to tackle distinct hydrologic issues, this study stands out for its application in building energy efficiency and meter reading automation. In this study, a dataset containing 700 images were collected and labeled from diverse water meter dials. To optimize the performance on constrained embedded devices, the image resolution was standardized to 192 × 192 post-collection. However, due to the limited dataset size, the neural network's capacity to generalize was compromised, leading to potential overfitting. To counter this, data augmentation techniques was adopted on the training set, yielding an expanded dataset of 1800 images. These methods included random adjustments in tone and brightness. This augmentation aids the model in handling variations in lighting conditions and camera settings. The introduction of hue enhancement also adds a random color channel modification, contributing to improved object edge and shape recognition. The application of turbine water flow is depicted in Fig. 8 . When analyzing the correlation between generated voltage and water flow rate, a plot is an essential visual tool to unveil insights. Fig. 9a presents a dual-axis plot juxtaposing the generator's output voltage and water velocity over sequential time intervals. The left y-axis delineates the water velocity, measured in liters per minute, revealing its fluctuating progression. Simultaneously, the right y-axis exhibits the corresponding output voltage in volts. This graphical representation provides a vivid depiction of how changes in water velocity might influence the generator's electrical output. Such a side-by-side portrayal facilitates a deeper understanding of the intrinsic relationship between the two variables, illuminating potential causality and offering pivotal insights for optimizing generator performance in fluid dynamics contexts. Fig. 9b explores the correlation between the output voltage of a generator and water velocity. This involved connecting both a generator and turbine flowmeters to the generator intakes, with the entire setup installed on a standard home faucet. The turbine flowmeter was chosen due to its capability to measure flow rates within the range of 1 to 50 liters per minute, effectively fulfilling the testing prerequisites. The output line of the generator was linked to a digital multimeter, enabling the collection of output voltage data (as shown in Fig. 9b). This experimental configuration aimed to investigate the interplay between the generator's electrical output and the velocity of water flow, offering insights into their relationship and potential implications. By plotting precision, recall, and F1-score metrics for each class, the visualization offers a clear snapshot of the system's detection accuracy. The peaks highlight areas where the model excels, while troughs indicate potential weak points that might require attention. Such a detailed, class-wise breakdown is invaluable for developers and researchers, allowing them to make informed decisions on model optimization, ensuring that the AVSM detection system achieves a consistent and high degree of accuracy across all object categories. The bottom graph contrasts water usage with conservation measures, showcasing the efforts and impacts of water-saving initiatives. Both visuals underline the consistent strive towards achieving eco-friendly building standards, emphasizing a shift towards sustainability in both energy and water domains. The histograms use different colors (blue for data1 and red for data2) with partial transparency (indicated by the alpha parameter) to differentiate them, while the grid and labels enhance the chart's readability. 5 Conclusion Integrating wireless water sensors and AVSM holds significant potential for enhancing building energy efficiency. By automating water metering through visual recognition, AVSM reduces manual labour and inaccuracies, contributing to optimized resource management. This synergy enables real-time monitoring, supporting informed decisions that align with sustainability goals and efficient energy consumption practices—proposing a novel wireless water consumption sensing system integrating machine learning and energy harvesting for accurate meter reading. Utilizing visual sensors and a lightweight AVSM model, it achieves precise data recognition without costly hardware. Self-sustainability is ensured through a micro water generator, reducing reliance on external power sources and enhancing building energy efficiency. In alignment with the study's objective, the AVSM-based wireless water consumption sensing system demonstrates promising results in accurately and efficiently monitoring water usage. The evaluation metrics showcase its proficiency, with an Average Precision (AP) of 0.75 and a Mean Average Precision (mAP) of 0.68. The system's robustness is evident in its high Intersection over Union (IoU) of 0.85 at a 0.5 threshold, accompanied by a commendable F1 Score of 0.72. The balanced performance is reflected in a Recall of 0.80 and a Precision of 0.78. Moreover, the system's low False Positive Rate (FPR) of 0.12 and False Negative Rate (FNR) of 0.20 attest to its reliability. These metrics collectively highlight the system's effectiveness inaccurate water consumption data recognition and support for building energy efficiency goals. In conclusion, integrating wireless water sensors and AVSM offers a progressive avenue to bolster building energy efficiency. This amalgamation streamlines water metering processes, curtails reliance on manual intervention, and fosters an environment of resource optimization. Potential research avenues could delve into AVSM's adaptability in various metering scenarios to pave the way for future advancements. Practical implementations should encompass collaborative efforts with stakeholders to ensure seamless integration, maximizing the potential for energy-efficient building management. coredata.dc:description: The use of smart wireless remote water meters has become popular due to their efficiency in avoiding manual labor and automate meter reading. The current implementation of these measurement instruments often requires expensive external power sources and separate data aggregators, posing challenges for circuit safety and the goal of reducing carbon emissions in aging communities. In response, a novel wireless system has been developed to accurately measure water consumption in buildings. This system incorporates advanced machine learning techniques and utilizes the potential of water-based energy in a seamless manner. This novel methodology utilizes optical sensors to acquire visual data of water gauges and exploits machine learning techniques, specifically the AVSM model also called Advanced Visual Sensing Model (AVSM). This methodology employs a rigorous approach to achieve accurate metric determinations, thereby eliminating the necessity for additional hardware or excessive power configurations. Moreover, an integrated micro water generator has been seamlessly implemented, demonstrating the capability to effectively transfer energy to a lithium battery for the purpose of storage. This implementation guarantees consistent functionality and a significant decrease in reliance on external power supplies. The data augmentation procedure involves the stochastic manipulation of image luminance, resulting in encouraging results when used in conjunction with the AVSM model. Significantly, the dimensions of the model have been significantly decreased, while maintaining a commendable mean average precision (mAP). By leveraging this method and visual-based features, the system can contribute to overall building energy efficiency and reduce the burdens of manual meter reading while supporting CO2 emissions reduction as a feasible and cost-effective solution for building management, promoting sustainability, and advancing energy-efficient practices in old communities. This new wireless system for measuring water usage provides a practical and affordable way to enhance energy efficiency in buildings, lessen the workload of manual meter reading, and help meet carbon emissions reduction goals. As well as optimizing resource and energy use, this method also aligns with eco-friendly solutions to combat global warming and climate change.
coredata.dc:title: Wireless water consumption sensing system for building energy efficiency: A visual-based approach with self-powered operation
